newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Polish c.bank head says rates on hold in near-term.
newsitem.headline: Polish c.bank head says rates on hold in near-term.

text.p: The National Bank of Poland President Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz on Monday said a change in official interest rates was unlikely in the near-term as credit growth remained a key issue for the central bank.

"Credit growth is too strong," Gronkiewicz-Waltz told Reuters in an interview, when asked about the central bank's most pressing problem. She was in Basle attending the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) annual meeting.
"I have increased the reserve requirements twice (this year) to curb credit growth...(and) for the moment I am waiting for the results," she added.
Gronkiewicz-Waltz said the central bank would likely refrain from increasing rates because such a move would cause unwanted foreign capital inflows.
"If I increased rates I could have a problem with capital inflow," Gronkiewicz-Waltz said.
On the other hand she said a reduction in rates would not be possible as this would create a problem with money supply, and added that there was too much money in the system.
The central bank last increased obligatory reserves on zloty term deposits and all foreign currency deposits to 11 and five percent respectively at the start of May. @
In February, the central bank increased reseves on zloty call deposits to 20 percent and to four percent on foreign currency deposits.
The central bank's official interest rates, now at 25 percent for the lombard and 22 percent for the discount, have remained unchanged from July last year.
